text: I mean certainly there are
representative artists in all the fields
um who did blossom in later life um I
think the ability to express oneself
artistically again it might be um a
worry and a question about social
stereotyping you know people might
assume that people as they get older are
going to decline in their capacity to be
creatively expressive so I mean just if
you talk to older actors about the um
about the you know the um the ability to
get roles in acting as an older actor
you know I think they would see that as
as greatly declining opportunity because
our society has sort of been biased
against you know the older person in
media in the Arts um so so there there's
a worry about being able to continue um
creative expression depending on the
field that you're in but um having said
that you know with aging comes great
life experience and um you know there's
a lot of interest in what happens to
brain function as people get older um
and a lot of worry about loss of memory
and dementia um but there's real you
know there's real data that wisdom is
something that is AC crud with life
experience and so there's that whole um
there's that whole field of experience
and wisdom which um which would kind of
feed into creativity and the older
person um being able to um you know
manifest their life's experience and
their wisdom so um so I certainly like
to um believe that one's ability to be
creative and and to grow I mean I think
um I think growing in new directions is
kind of a Hallmark of successful aging
so um some of the you know historically
interesting um figures who really aged
well um took up uh new forms of creative
expression um as they got older like
Grandma Moses you know the artist or um
it said that Albert Einstein I believe
took up playing the violin in late life
and so um so uh exploring new routes of
creativity um is one of the Hallmarks of
of people who age
well um you know one of the most
effective ways of uh keeping your brain
function as you get older is to stay
healthy in general um we know that for
instance all of the risk factors that
you hear about for heart disease um for
instance high blood pressure diabetes
smoking you know having an an active
lifestyle um th all of those things that
put you at risk in other Realms of
Health are also um risk factors for
brain disease and and Alzheimer's
disease so um so you know staying
healthy it's all all the things that you
kind of wish weren't the things you had
to do because they're not the easy
things to do you know we we all want to
be able to pop a pill and that's going
to preserve our memory but it's really
um you know eating a healthy diet um
staying Physically Active I mean if I
had to say the one thing that that
people really should try to do beginning
in early life that will have huge um
payback you know as they get older is is
creating habits of physical activity you
know being an active person I mean
that's just I call it the real Fountain
of Youth it really is I mean exercise
has been shown to prevent many diseases
that are associated with aging and it's
all it's also been to really um maintain
brain function as well so you know
eating a healthy diet staying Physically
Active um continuing to be mentally and
socially engaged
um uh continuing to be involved in
whatever whatever is your passion you
know to really be engaged with life um
those have all been shown to really
promote um preserved brain function we
still don't you know we still don't know
what causes Alzheimer's disease and that
is just a subject of a huge amount of
research going on so um so of course
it's true that brilliant people get
Alzheimer's disease and you know it's a
very tragic um disease but if you look
at you know the whole population um if
people pursued healthier Lifestyles that
would that would be a big Plus in terms
of preserving brain function across the
population
there's just reams of research data that
prove that point um that physical
activity is um you know as I said it it
plays out as um preventing many diseases
um it's a it's a strong predictor of
mortality um if you look at uh and this
has you know been shown in numerous
research studies if you look at people's
Exercise capacity how able they are to
be vigorously active um it's a very
strong predictor of how long you live
and for each you know increment up on
the scale you are a physical activity um
the longer you would be I mean it would
predict for your length of life the good
news is that you know you don't have to
be a marathon runner I mean if you're so
because you know people get discouraged
they're like well I've been a couch
potato All My Life um but if you even go
from like the lowest quartile of
physical activity to the second to the
lowest quartile you really improve your
your um your health status um and as I
said you know just a broad range of
diseases whether it's hypertension heart
disease colon cancer depression diabetes
I mean you know I could read a long list
but all of those things are reduced in
incidents in people that are physically
active so and you know that's the
tragedy too of what we're seeing now um
I mean I really look at at young people
now even kids I mean you know as a
geriatrician I'm really coming to see
more and more that everything begins in
early life so you know the fact that
kids now aren't active you know they're
not going out to ride their bikes and
explore the neighborhood they're sitting
at home be you know behind their
computers which I mean there's some
there's some benefit there too I I think
that um modern day access to information
is just remarkable but um you know kids
not being Physically Active you know
recess being done away with at schools
and um and the the rate of childhood
obesity is just terribly frightening
it's considered one of the leading
Public Health you know issues in this
country is the rate of childhood obesity
because that is just going to play out
into you know adults being obese it's
it's already a huge number um and it's
it's said that now this next Generation
Um as the Baby Boomers move into the
elderly age group it might start to be
true that people live less Long than
their than their parents and that's
going to be because obesity which really
a big part of it is that obesity leading
to type 2 diabetes and all of the
problems with with diabetes and
premature death so you know it's really
scary um so I kind of you know I really
applaud all the efforts that are going
on now to try to to turn that around to
um reduce obesity to get kids to be more
active I think that's really going to be
a key to what you know what we're seeing
down the line in terms of the elderly
